forecast.review: Both forecasters make solid points about fragility given the dense early-May catalyst calendar and elevated valuations/volatility. Forecaster 2’s framing that one or two disappointments could outweigh multiple benign outcomes is a useful distribution-skew argument I hadn’t emphasized enough. Forecaster 3 adds the risk of profit-taking after a sharp rebound; that’s plausible, though their “high bar” point relies on April’s month-end level, not April 25, and we don’t yet know the April close. Neither adds concrete new data, but both sharpen the downside-tail narrative. I’d push back slightly that a VIX near 25 can also coincide with stronger-than-average forward returns as risk premia rise, and that the cap-weighting/mega-cap earnings concentration can swing the month on a few beats/guides. Overall, their reasoning nudges me modestly lower, but not below 50%, given base rates and momentum.
forecast.rationale: Starting from a historical monthly base rate modestly above 50%, I previously set 56% on the view that mega-cap earnings and recent momentum could carry May, while acknowledging elevated valuations, VIX ~25, and a crowded macro/earnings calendar. After weighing the others’ arguments, I see a slightly more asymmetric near-term risk: with high multiples and many binary events (big tech earnings, PCE, payrolls, and a potentially hawkish-leaning Fed on May 7), it may only take a couple of negative surprises to flip the month red. Tariff-related margins/guide risks and sticky inflation risks remain live. That said, the cap-weighted nature of the S&P 500, ongoing AI-related demand tailwinds for mega-cap tech, and typical buy-the-dip behavior argue against taking this below 50%. Netting these, I trim my probability modestly from 56% to 53%.
